Graphical abstract Supercritical water gasification of ethanol production residue from eucalyptus powder was studied over a graphite-supported 5wt% ruthenium catalyst (Ru/G) in a batch reaction system. The complete gasification of 0.1g of the residue proceeded over 0.05g of Ru/G at 673K in supercritical water with 0.5gcm−3 water density. The gasification behavior of the residue from eucalyptus was compared with that from Japanese cedar to evaluate the potential of fuel gas production from bioethanol production residue. The gasification profiles (gaseous yield and selectivity) of the resides were well reproduced by the linear combination of those of woody biomass fractions (lignin and cellulose). Keywords Supercritical water Gasification Methanation 1 Introduction The development of catalytic partial decomposition of plant biomass and the subsequent catalytic transformation of the decomposed chemical blocks for the production of useful platform chemicals, which are currently synthesized by chemical processing of the fossil fuel, would contribute to the establishment of sustainable way of production of chemicals. Ideally, catalytic processes that utilize all the constituents of plant biomass are desirable; however, only the partial usage of constituents of biomass, e.g. cellulose, is until now in progress and other waste fractions, e.g. lignin, are incineration and/or disposal in land filling. The disposal of biomass waste by incineration does not cause much of carbon dioxide emission, because most of the carbon dioxide is utilized for the regrowth of the plant via photosynthesis. However, the thermal recovery by incineration of waste plant biomass is not so efficient as it contains water and drying processes of wet biomass needs energy. Ethanol production from food resources, such as starch and sucrose, has been commercialized to provide alternative or additives to gasoline [1–6]. The development of manufacturing processes for the production of ethanol from wood-derived cellulose is desirable not only because the competition between energy and food could be eliminated, but also larger amounts of cellulose can be available from woody biomass than those from herbaceous biomass per unit area of land [7–10]. The problem for the utilization of woody biomass for ethanol production is the treatment of the residue which is mainly a lignin fraction. The residue contains moisture and a drying pretreatment is needed for the thermal recovery by its incineration. Synthetic gas (carbon monoxide and hydrogen) can be obtained by steam reforming of the dried woody powder using nickel catalysts; however, high temperature more than 1000K is needed and this process suffers from fast deactivation of the catalyst by coking. Supercritical water gasification technique (critical point of water: 647.3K and 22.1MPa) is a prospective way to utilize low-quality wastes and provides fuel gases (methane and hydrogen) from woody biomass using supported metal catalysts [11–16]. The structural stability of the catalyst in supercritical water is important for the development of gasification catalysts, and ruthenium is the most effective metal species while supports like carbon (charcoal [17–19], carbon nanotube [20], and graphite [21]), titania [16,17,22], zirconia [23], and α-alumina [24] are most suitable in supercritical water media. There are several reports for the development of catalytic gasification of organosolv lignin [17–19] and real biomass containing lignin, such as sawdust [24], bagasse [25], bark [26], and a residue from a saccharification process in a bioethanol production system from Japanese cedar, which is a softwood, over supported ruthenium catalysts in supercritical water [27]. We have reported that complete gasification of organosolv lignin proceeded over a graphite supported ruthenium catalyst, having 1.5wt% ruthenium metal loading, in supercritical water [21]. The supercritical gasification also proceeded over a charcoal supported ruthenium catalyst with 1.5wt% of ruthenium loading; however, the complete gasification could not be obtained under the same reaction condition. Different gasification yields were obtained between the graphite supported and charcoal supported ruthenium catalysts, which could be explained by the gasification mechanism of organosolv lignin and the structure of supported ruthenium catalysts. Organosolv lignin was hydrolyzed to small molecules, such as alkylphenols, formaldehyde, and glycerin and the small molecules are gasified over ruthenium metal particles in supercritical water [12]. The size of ruthenium metal particles in the graphite supported catalyst are almost the same as that of the charcoal supported catalyst; however most of ruthenium metal particles are located on flat plate-like graphite particles with few micropore and parts of ruthenium metal particles in micropores in the charcoal-supported catalyst. Easy accessibility of hydrolyzed small molecules from organosolv lignin in supercritical water to ruthenium metal particles on the flat graphite surfaces enables the complete gasification [21]. In this study, we report the gasification of an ethanol production residue from eucalyptus, which is a hard wood, in supercritical water with the graphite supported ruthenium metal catalyst. Based on comparative study with the gasification behavior (in terms of yield, TOF, and gaseous selectivity) of organosolv lignin and cellulose, which are model fractions of woody biomass, and also the saccharification residue from cedar powder, we discuss (i) the potential of the graphite supported ruthenium metal catalyst for the gasification of residue, and (ii) the effect of kind of wood type and cellulose fraction on the catalytic gasification of residue from woody biomass in supercritical water media. 2 Experimental The sample preparation of sulfuric acid free solid residue from eucalyptus for ethanol production process is described as follows [28]. Eucalyptus powder pulverized in a disk mill was treated with cellulase and yeast for simultaneous saccharification and fermentation. Following to the separation of the prepared slurry by filtration, the solid residue was washed with distilled water, and then the residue was dried at 378K for 12h. The solid residue from Japanese cedar powder was obtained as follows. Following the saccharification of Japanese cedar already pulverized in a tandem-ring mill, the solid fraction was filtered, washed with distilled water, and then, dried at 378K for 12h [29,30]. Reference samples, organosolv lignin and cellulose powder were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich Cooperation. All the chemicals were used without further purification. The elementary composition was determined by ultimate CHNS analyzer (CE Instruments EA1110) and O analyzer (CE Instruments EA1112). For the composition analysis, the lignin content in the residue samples was determined as insoluble in aqueous 72% sulfuric acid solution [31] and the holocellulose (total polysaccharide composed of cellulose and hemicellulose) content was determined as insoluble in hypochlorous acid [32]. The catalysts were prepared with an impregnation method using 1.5% aqueous solution of ruthenium(III) nitrosyl nitrate (STREM Chemicals) and graphite powder (TCI HSAG300, surface area 300m2 g−1), followed by the treatment under flowing hydrogen at 573K for 2h [21]. The ruthenium metal loading for the catalyst was 5wt%. Catalytic gasification was conducted in a stainless-steel 316 reactor with an internal volume of 6cm3. Known amounts of catalyst, organic sample (residue, organosolv lignin, and cellulose for the respective gasification), and 3g of water were charged to the reactor; the amount of water corresponded to a density of 0.5gcm−3. The air inside the reactor was removed by purging with argon gas. The reactor was submerged into a preheated sand bath (ACRAFT, model AT-1B) at 673K and the internal temperature of the reactor was monitored by a K-type thermocouple. The reaction period reported here includes the heating up period (5min) also. Although we did not measure the partial pressure of water inside the reactor at 673K it was estimated to be as high as 37MPa [33]. After a given reaction time, the reactor was taken out from the sand bath and submerged into a water bath for rapid cooling to room temperature. Gaseous products were collected by a syringe and injected through sampling loops attached to a gas chromatograph for its analysis by a thermal conductivity detector (Shimadzu, model GC-8A) using a Shincarbon ST column. After the gaseous products were sampled, the remaining products in the reactor were recovered with pure water and separated as water-soluble and water-insoluble fractions. Because the water-insoluble solid fraction also contained the catalysts used, we evaluated the amount of water-insoluble products by subtracting the weight of the catalyst charged from the former. The amounts of organic carbon in the water-soluble fractions were evaluated using a total organic carbon analyzer (Shimadzu, model TOC-V). The product yield based on the amount of carbon and the gas composition are defined as given below, (1) product yield based on carbon ( C % ) = moles of carbon in the product moles of carbon in the reactant sample × 100 (2) gas composition ( % ) = moles of gaseous product sum of moles of gaseous product × 100 The turnover number of Ru/G is defined as given below, (3) turnover number ( TON ) = moles of carbon in the gaseous product moles of surface ruthenium atoms in Ru/G Some experiments were repeated three times to quantify run to run variability. The average of these trials was included in the figures along with the standard deviations. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Residue sample The elemental analysis of the eucalyptus residue, organosolv lignin and cellulose is shown in Table 1 . The carbon content value of the residue from eucalyptus was lower than that of the organosolv lignin sample but higher than that of the cellulose sample. On the other hand, the oxygen content in the residue sample was higher than that of the organosolv lignin sample but lower than that of the cellulose sample. The residue sample contained 0.9% nitrogen, which would be derived from cellulase and/or yeast used for saccharification and/or fermentation; however, it should be emphasized that the residue sample did not contain any sulfur. The composition analysis by sulfuric acid treatment showed that the weight percentage of lignin fraction in the eucalyptus residue sample was 54%. On the other hand, the weight percentage of holocellulose fraction, which was composed of hemicellulose fraction and unsaccharized cellulose, in the residue sample was 36% by hypochlorous acid treatment. Some part of cellulose fraction having low-molecular weight would be removed during hypochlorous acid treatment [27], then the summation of lignin and holocellulose fractions was lower than 100%. 3.2 Decomposition of residue in supercritical water Fig. 1 (a) shows the decomposition profile of the 0.10g of ethanol production residue from eucalyptus in supercritical water with 0.5gcm−3 water density in the absence of Ru/G. The gas from the eucalyptus residue was only 18% at 15min and slightly increased to 20% at 90min. A highly viscous solid material, char, was observed in the reaction tube from the beginning of the reaction. We have reported that 15% of gas yield at 15min while it slightly increased to 20% at 90min in the saccharification residue from Japanese cedar, which contained 72% of lignin, in supercritical water [27]. Osada et al. reported that char was formed at an early stage of the decomposition of organosolv lignin in supercritical water, and proposed the char formation mechanism that carbon-oxygen-carbon single bonds in the lignin fraction were hydrolyzed in supercritical water to form alkylphenols, formaldehyde, and glycerin, and these compounds repolymerized to form char by cross-linking reactions occurring in supercritical water [17]. While, Yamaguchi et al. reported that condensation of glycerin by intermolecular dehydration proceeded to form char in high-temperature water [32]. Similar to the decomposition mechanism of organosolv lignin in supercritical water, alkylphenols, formaldehyde, glycerin, and polyols were formed by the hydrolysis of lignin and holocellulose fractions in the eucalyptus residue at the early stage in supercritical water and the condensation reaction between these hydrolyzed molecules proceeded to form insoluble polymeric char. Due to this fact, the yield of gaseous and water-soluble products did not increase even when the reaction time increased to 180min. The composition of the gaseous products formed in the eucalyptus residue gasification is shown in (b). At 15min, 75% carbon dioxide (CO2), 15% methane (CH4), 8% hydrogen (H2), and 2% C2–C4 (ethane, propane, and butane) were obtained. Although CO2 slightly decreased while CH4 increased with increasing reaction time, the composition of the gas products was almost independent of the reaction time. The CO2 selectivity in the gaseous product from the saccharification residue from Japanese cedar was 65% at 15min which slightly decreased with increase in gasification [27]. Because the content of holocellulose in the eucalyptus residue (46%) was higher than that in Japanese cedar (28%), higher CO2 selectivity would be observed from the beginning of decomposition of the former in supercritical water. 3.3 Gasification over Ru/G in supercritical water We characterized the ruthenium metal particles on graphite. The carbon monoxide adsorption measurement showed that the ruthenium metal dispersion value for Ru/G having 5wt% of ruthenium loading was 0.48 and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images showed that the average ruthenium metal particle size in Ru/G was 1.6nm. Similar high dispersion (0.48) and small metal particle size (1.7nm) values were obtained for a graphite supported ruthenium catalyst having 1.5wt% of ruthenium loading from graphite powder (HSAG300) and ruthenium(III) nitrosyl nitrate [21]. We treated 0.10g of the eucalyptus residue with 0.05g of Ru/G in water at 673K and 0.5gcm−3 water density for 240min, and 100% of carbon yield was obtained, which shows that Ru/G was active for the supercritical gasification of the residue from ethanol production from eucalyptus, which did not contain any sulfur species. The composition of the gaseous products over Ru/G was 40% CO2, 55% CH4, 4% H2, and 1% C2–C4. The atomic ratio in the gaseous products by the supercritical gasification over the Ru/G catalyst for carbon: hydrogen: oxygen (C:H:O) was 1.0:2.3:0.9. On the other hand, the C:H:O atomic ratio of the residue sample was 1.0:1.3:0.5, which means that the gas produced by gasification contained more hydrogen and oxygen than the residue sample itself. From the difference of the atomic ratios of the residue and gaseous products, the amount of hydrogen and oxygen increased by 1.0 and 0.4, respectively and the ratio of hydrogen and oxygen for the increased amount was approximately 2:1. It is probable that water-shift (C+H2O→CO+H2) and water-gas-shift (CO+H2O→CO2 +H2) reactions proceeded over Ru/G during the supercritical water gasification reaction, and that water acted not only as a solvent but also as a reactant during the gasification process [17,24]. A gasification profile of the ethanol production residue from eucalyptus sample over Ru/G at 673K in water with a density of 0.5gcm−3 water is shown in Fig. 2 . The gaseous yield at 15min was 47% (Fig. 2(a)), leading to TON value of 173. The water-soluble product was also produced at 15min by the supercritical gasification over Ru/G. The gaseous yield increased while that of the water-soluble products decreased with an increase in time. It is plausible that the residue sample was decomposed into the water-soluble fraction in supercritical water, leading to the gasification of the water-soluble fraction over Ru/G. Here, we emphasize that the residue sample was completely gasified over Ru/G without forming char by cross-linking of water-soluble products. Fig. 2 (b) shows the profile of gaseous product composition. At the beginning of the reaction (15min), the composition of gaseous products was 50% CO2, 30% CH4, 13% H2, and 7% C2–C4 gases. The amount of CH4 increased, whereas those of CO2 and H2 decreased as the reaction proceeded, indicating that methanation (CO+3H2 →CH4 +H2O) proceeded over ruthenium catalysts during gasification under supercritical conditions [18]. Fig. 3 shows the gasification profile of 0.1g of model components in the residue over 0.05g of Ru/G at 673K in water with 0.50gcm−3 water density. For the gasification of organosolv lignin (Fig. 3(a)), the gaseous carbon yield was 26% at 15min, from which TON was calculated to be 120. The TON value for organosolv lignin was lower than that for the eucalyptus residue (173). In the gaseous product 47% CO2, 32% CH4, 16% H2, and 6% C2–C4 were included (Fig. 3(b)). The gas yield increased with an increase in reaction time; however, we could not obtain the complete gasification yield under this reaction condition. We separately confirmed that more than 99% of the gas yield could be obtained by the gasification of 0.10g organosolv lignin with 0.15g of Ru/G at 673K in supercritical water with 0.50gcm−3 water. Organosolv lignin was hydrolyzed to small molecules, such as alkylphenols and formaldehyde, in supercritical water [17]. These small molecules were partially gasified over Ru/G; however, some of them could be repolymerized to produce char under the reaction conditions given in Fig. 3, because the amount of Ru/G introduced was not sufficient for complete gasification. Fig. 3 (c) and (d) show the gasification profile of 0.10g of 4-n-propylphenol, which can be considered as a model fragment of lignin, over 0.05g of Ru/G catalyst at 673K in water with 0.50gcm−3 water density. The gasification proceeded with time and 4-n-propylphenol was completely gasified after 60min, indicating that 0.05g of Ru/G was enough for gasification of 0.10g 4-n-propylphenol. In case of 4-n-propylphenol gasification, repolymerization did not occur in supercritical water because cross-linker, such as formaldehyde, did not exist in the system. Also, (a) and (c) shows that the gasification rate of 4-n-propylphenol was higher than that of organosolv lignin, indicating that hydrolysis rate of lignin by supercritical water was lower than that of 4-n-propylphenol gasification. Fig. 3(e) and (f) shows the gasification profile of 0.10g of cellulose with 0.05g Ru/G at 673K in water with 0.50gcm−3 water density. The gaseous carbon yield and TON at 15min were 76% and 221, respectively. Cellulose was converted into gaseous products with 90% yield within 30min of reaction and more than 99% of gaseous yield was obtained within 60min, with the gas composition as 50% CH4, 44% CO2, and 6% H2. The TON order over Ru/G in supercritical water was “cellulose (221)>eucalyptus residue (173)>organosolv lignin (119)”. From the composition analysis, the lignin fraction of the eucalyptus residue was 54%. Because it is reported that the reaction behavior of hemicellulose in supercritical water is similar to that of cellulose [13], we presumed that gasification behavior of hemicellulose is almost the same as that of cellulose. The calculated TON value for a mixture of 0.54g of organosolv lignin and 0.46g of cellulose was 166, which is near to that for the eucalyptus residue. 3.4 Interaction between biomass fractions in the gasification of ethanol production residue from eucalyptus We studied the reaction behavior of a physical mixture of model compounds of organosolv lignin and cellulose and compared it with that for the eucalyptus residue to study the interactions between the biomass fractions present in the residue during gasification process. From the component analysis, we used a physical mixture of 0.55g organosolv lignin and 0.45g cellulose. The gasification behavior of the mixture of organosolv lignin and cellulose (red symbols in Fig. 4 ) was practically identical to that of the residue (black symbols in Fig. 4, data is the same as in Fig. 2), along with the compositions of the gaseous product. The results shown in Fig. 4 indicate that the gasification of lignin and cellulose over Ru/G occurred simultaneously during the gasification of the residue sample. Some interactions between lignin and cellulose present in the residue would be possible; however, we could conclude that such interactions had no effect on the gasification in supercritical water as evidenced by the results shown in Fig. 4. 3.5 Comparison with gasification behavior of softwood In order to understand the effect of wood type and the amount of lignin content on the gasification of the residue from ethanol production, we compared the gasification behavior of residue after saccharization of Japanese cedar [27], which contained 72% of lignin, with that of the eucalyptus residue over Ru/G in water at 673K. Fig. 5 shows the gasification profile of 0.1g of the residue after saccharization of Japanese cedar over Ru/G [27]. The gaseous yield and TON at 15min were 37% and 144, respectively. The calculated TON value for a mixture of 0.7g of organosolv lignin and 0.3g of cellulose was 149, which is near to that for the Japanese cedar residue. Water-soluble products were also formed with 20% yield at 15min. The gaseous yield increased and the water-soluble yield decreased with an increase in time (Fig. 5(a)). After 240min, the yield of gaseous products based on carbon content was 100%, and neither the water-soluble fraction nor char was formed at 240min over Ru/G. Fig. 5(b) shows the profile of gaseous product composition. At the beginning of the reaction (15min), the composition of gaseous products was 32% CH4, 47% CO2, 15% H2, and 6% C2–C4 gases. The amount of CH4 increased, whereas those of CO2 and H2 decreased as the reaction proceeded. When the entire carbon content of the residue was gasified at 240min, the composition of the gas obtained was 53% CH4, 41% CO2, 4% H2, and 2% C2–C4. The reaction behavior of a physical mixture of 0.07g of organosolv lignin and 0.03g of cellulose was also studied (red symbol in Fig. 5) and compared with the result of the saccharification of Japanese cedar, which contained 72% of lignin. The gasification behavior of the mixture of organosolv lignin and cellulose was practically identical to that of the saccharification of Japanese cedar. Both the residues from saccharification of cedar and from ethanol production from eucalyptus were completely gasified in 240min; however, the initial gasification rate for the sample from the eucalyptus residue was higher. Both residue samples would be decomposed in a similar manner to the water-soluble fraction in supercritical water. However, the lignin content in the eucalyptus residue (54%) is less than that from Japanese cedar residue (72%), indicating that smaller amounts of alkylphenol molecules would exist than that from Japanese cedar residue in supercritical water. Therefore, initial gasification rate for eucalyptus residue would be higher than that from the cedar residue sample. Interestingly, the selectivity to final gaseous products obtained from eucalyptus residue (55% CH4, 40% CO2, 4% H2, and 1% C2–C4 gases) were almost the same as that from cedar residue (53% CH4, 41% CO2, 4% H2, and 2% C2–C4 gases). The gasification mechanism, which includes the gasification of alkylphenols, glycerin, and polyols formed from hydrolyzed residue involving methanation, water gas shift reaction, and water shift reaction, would be the same for the both the residue, hence resulting into the similar selectivities (equilibrium selectivities) after 240min of gasification. 4 Conclusion We studied the gasification behavior of eucalyptus residue with the Ru/G catalyst in supercritical water. (1) 0.1g of the eucalyptus residue was completely gasified with the 0.05g Ru/G catalyst at 673K in supercritical water with 0.5gcm−3 water density and a gaseous mixture containing 55% CH4, 40% CO2, 4% H2, and 1% C2–C4 gases was obtained. (2) The gasification behavior (TON and gas composition) of the residue from eucalyptus over Ru/G in supercritical water was reproduced by linear combination of the mixture of organosolv lignin and cellulose. (3) The initial TON value of Ru/G of the eucalyptus residue containing 54% lignin for the supercritical water gasification was higher than that of the saccharification residue from Japanese cedar containing 72% of lignin. The final gaseous selectivities were almost the same for both the resources. Acknowledgements We thank Dr. Sakanishi and Dr. Hirata of Biomass Technology Research Center of AIST for providing the eucalyptus residue sample. We also thank Prof. Takahashi (Akita Prefectural University) and Dr. Enda (Akita Industrial Technology Center) for providing the Japanese cedar residue sample. coredata.dc:description: Supercritical water gasification of ethanol production residue from eucalyptus powder was studied over a graphite-supported 5wt% ruthenium catalyst (Ru/G) in a batch reaction system. The complete gasification of 0.1g of the residue proceeded over 0.05g of Ru/G at 673K in supercritical water with 0.5gcm−3 water density. The gasification behavior of the residue from eucalyptus was compared with that from Japanese cedar to evaluate the potential of fuel gas production from bioethanol production residue. The gasification profiles (gaseous yield and selectivity) of the resides were well reproduced by the linear combination of those of woody biomass fractions (lignin and cellulose).
coredata.dc:title: Supercritical water gasification of ethanol production waste over graphite supported ruthenium catalyst
